snippet: For potential voters in hardscrabble Russian towns, any desire to live better is outweighed by a persistent fear of living worse.
abstract: There is a sense among voters in hardscrabble Russian towns like Lyubertsy of teetering on the edge, and any desire to live better is outweighed by a persistent fear of living worse; a significant factor in the presidential election is that most feel that life is better than in the 1990s; it is a sentiment that sounds alien in Moscow, where Putin has faced a challenge from a boisterous, though largely isolated, movement of urban elites whose ambitions and self-regard have outgrown the rigid confines of his rule.

byline.contributor: Anastasia Sadovskaya contributed reporting from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: For potential voters in hardscrabble Russian towns, any desire to live better is outweighed by a persistent fear of living worse.

headline.seo: In Russia Vote, Fear of Hardship Fuels Putin Support
headline.main: Fear of Return to ’90s Hardship Fuels Support for Putin
headline.print_headline: For Struggling Russians, Fear of Return to Hardship of ’90s Fuels Support for Putin
